@Stimuleye `sudo some-command` will prompt you to enter the root user's password, because `some-command` will be executed with root user privileges. You will have set the password this during your os setup.

Here's what I believe @rohitchugh1983 did:
```
$ sudo npm install -g npm@6
$ npm install -g truffle
```

However you shouldn't have to use `sudo`, [our recommendation](https://github.com/trufflesuite/truffle#install) is to use [nvm](https://github.com/nvm-sh/nvm) which manages your node versions and avoids permission errors like that one you encountered. Thanks.

Using `sudo` this way is potentially dangerous as you are giving packages root access to your machine. WE DO NOT RECOMMEND DOING THIS!

Usually this issue is resolved by re-installing Node and npm with a Node version manager such as nvm, and this is in fact what npm itself recommends. You can check out [this article](https://docs.npmjs.com/resolving-eacces-permissions-errors-when-installing-packages-globally) from npm that gives more info on doing this. It usually resolved permissions errors that people encounter.
